description: From Anglo-Norman ouster, oustier, from Old French oster (modern French ôter), from post-classical Latin obstare (“to remove”), classical obstāre (“to obstruct, stand in the way of”).

verbs.description: oust (third-person singular simple present ousts, present participle ousting, simple past and past participle ousted)

examples: The protesters became so noisy that they were finally ousted from the meeting.
The CEO was ousted by the board of directors.
